properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm weather will continue. Time span: today through Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: near 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over most of central and northeastern Newfoundland for the next couple of days. Beyond Wednesday, there is more uncertainty as to how long the heat will persist. Some forecast guidance is suggesting the high temperatures may last through the rest of the week for some areas while other guidance has a bit of a cool down on Thursday into Friday. More details for later in the week will follow in subsequent forecasts. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-07-21T05:35:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T13:36:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0590521930.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very high temperatures and humidity are expected for much of Nova Scotia. Time span: continuing until Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 32 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 16 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: Nova Scotia. Remarks: Temperatures reaching 32 degrees Celsius, humidex 36, combined with overnight lows near 16 degrees Celsius are expected for the next few days. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T06:03:31-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very high temperatures and humidity are expected for much of New Brunswick. Time span: continuing until Tuesday or Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 32 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: eastern and central New Brunswick. Remarks: temperatures reaching 32 degrees Celsius and a humidex reaching 39, combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius, are expected for the next few days in southern New Brunswick. In northeastern New Brunswick, very warm temperatures today and tonight are expected to cool below warning criteria on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T06:07:24-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very warm and humid conditions are expected for much of Prince Edward Island. Time span: today. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 18 degrees. Remarks: a very warm airmass will maintain hot and humid conditions today. Cooler temperatures are expected on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Maximum rainfall rates: locally 25 mm per hour. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h. Locations: parts of central and southwestern New Brunswick. Time span: mid afternoon till this evening. Remarks: A line of severe thunderstorms could form this afternoon over southwestern New Brunswick and track towards the east into the evening along a cold front. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T01:59:44-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog will likely persist most of the day today due to a moist easterly flow off Hudson Strait. It should begin to gradually disperse this evening as winds shift slightly more northerly. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T04:59:33-00:00
